annotation.TEXT: With this done however, what's next? Well, the Make a Good Mega Man Level Contest (or "MAGMML" for short) was completed and released as a full game recently, so I can't exactly pass that one up. Beyond that, there's a ton of other fan-games that are still in development, though we might see in the future.

Just to name a few: We have Mega Man Recharged, Infamous Intent, Revolution Remix, Y+1, FD, Square Root 2, Rockman Infinity 3, Eternal 2, X Corrupted, and MMBN Chrono X, all currently underway from the look of things. I'd also like to give special mention to Mega Man Zeta, which seemingly came out of nowhere recently, but still a pleasant surprise and neat addition to the list of upcoming fan-games.

Of course, all of those games will be for another time (read: "Whenever they get released"). For now, I plan on tackling MAGMML and whatever else comes next. If needed, I have a few minor video ideas in mind to fill in any potential gaps, along with a back-up plan in case of a severe game drought (which I'd rather not resort to. Maybe I'll do it as a part of a Halloween special, maybe not. We'll see how things go).

With that being said, the fight is now completely trivialized by Shark Boomerang. If I had one suggestion for this fight, it would be to make CRORQ immune to this weapon. As it is now, you can pretty much breeze through both phases without ever having to interact with the boss' main gimmick.

Come to think of it, this game actually has a rather varied set of fortress stages; Outside areas, a train, a hologram zone, the inside of a mecha-dragon, etc. The only other game that does that sort of thing is Rock Force (even though it only had 3 fortress stages, all of them were still very different).

The next stage is a bit interesting, in that it somewhat serves as a boss rush tied in with the level itself. Thankfully, this isn't like MM1's boss rush (where it just crams most of them in at the very end). Instead, the bosses appear after going through portions of the stage. With that being said, not all 8 Robot Masters show up here (so in turn, I guess that gives it at least one similarity to MM1's final stage).

The real final boss is more of an auto-scroll/chase sequence than anything. It also determines a small factor during the ending sequence of the game. It all depends on whether or not you reduce Wily's health bar completely (thankfully, the game gives you enough time to beat him down towards the end).

The Wily Golem isn't anything too special. All of its attacks can be avoided by sticking to roughly the center of the screen and jumping (specifically whenever it uses its fire breath). Naturally though, this isn't the true final boss.

To quote Grenade Man: "That felt good!" It feels like I've finally closed a long overdue chapter in my catalog of games. As I said before when playing the initial version, I really do hate dropping games mid-playthrough. Sometimes it has to be done for various reasons, but overall, I'd rather avoid doing so if I can help it.

Overall, this goes to show what a few improvements can do for a project. Granted, this game still has its faults (the iffy sliding, CRORQ being underwhelming due to the Shark Boomerang, and I would personally prefer a save feature over a password system, just to name a few things). In the end however, this game has definitely come through.

There's also a visual gimmick relating to those hologram machines, switching up the look of the stage every now and then. Even though the general idea of this sort of thing isn't anything new, I still think it's a nice touch when done right (mostly since it helps to break up the usual "generic techno backgrounds" that make up most Fortress stages).

The idea behind this version of CRORQ hasn't changed much, but the fight itself has been cleaned up a bit. You're essentially meant to shoot at the sides in order to produce platforms and raise them up slightly (thereby giving you a way to reach and shoot at the turret above). In the original version, Mega Man would always slip off the platforms, making it impossible to fight CRORQ without weapons. Gratefully, this is no longer an issue here.

While not the best fan-game out there, I feel that the revamped version still warrants a playthrough. The path changing mechanics for each stage (along with some of the bosses changing) are unique enough on their own to look into. Plus, it has one of the most diverse fortresses when it comes to fan-games (or just Mega Man games in general).
